Elliotte Harold wrote:

> What would the output from this be? i.e. what does it look like when the
> test fails? Can I easily tell with which parameter it's breaking? 

What do you think of J. B. Rainsberger's suggestion of adding a test 
name to each set of parameters?  Would that address these concerns?

> and
> can I easily debug just that case?

One advantage of the JUnit 4 syntax is that it's possible to think of 
IDE test runtimes being able to debug a single test case from the 
parameters, whereas I can't imagine how to make Eclipse do this with 
JUnit 3 parameterized test cases.

>
> One of the things I like about the current JUnit 3 non-parameterized
> approach is that when something does fail, I can immediately reproduce
> it to step through in a debugger. 

This certainly shouldn't be seen as a replacement of any 
non-parameterized JUnit 3 tests.  The goal, which I could have stated 
more usefully up front, was this: JUnit 4, out of the box, does not 
provide a dynamic test-suite building mechanism such as that provided by 
the static suite() method in JUnit 3.  One reason to use suite() is to 
dynamically build a set of TestCase objects that implement the 
Parameterized Test Case pattern (see _JUnit Recipes_, recipe 4.8).  
JUnit 4 does not provide a suite() mechanism, so the JUnit developers 
would like to find an alternate way to accomplish the same goal in JUnit 4.

The common case in JUnit 4 will be non-parameterized tests, just as it 
was in JUnit < 4.

    David Saff
